Part 3, Chapter 9, Section 3: Benefiting and Blessing, 15 main biographies, 1 person's biography appended. Biography of Zhihui of the Zhongtan Bathhouse in Luoyang, Later Tang Dynasty. Shi Zhihui, whose surname was Gao, was from Xianqin.
When he was young, he had the intention to leave secular life. He did not associate with children in play, but always followed his own destiny.

Suddenly he met Chan Master Wen of Guifeng, whose appearance was majestic and awe-inspiring. Those who approached him with an empty mind to understand the Way were distinguished by their virtue and sincerity.
He said to Zhihui:
You are truly a person with great potential and many abilities.
He requested to be accepted as a disciple.
At twenty, he received full ordination. His demeanor was outstanding, and he favored the extraordinary.

In the mountains, it was quiet and still, with nothing else to do, he only studied the scriptures and teachings, and was well-versed in Chan and Vinaya, reciting hundreds of thousands of words daily, savoring their meaning.
Hearing that the Buddha allowed studying other teachings for a while, he was quite skilled in poetry and composition, mastering the styles of the Sao and Ya.
His calligraphy was excellent, and his small script was especially wonderful. When he was inspired to paint on a wall, the clouds and mountains were in the palm of his hand.
He often said:
I admire Sengzhen and Daofen's six methods, but regret not being able to be contemporaries, facing the wall and drawing together, each creating the vividness of objects.
But he was truly a free and easy person!ğŸ”½Sometimes he would travel with his staff, enjoying the scenery of mountains and waters;
Sometimes he would go on foot, visiting the markets and cities.
If he found a place to his liking, he would stay; if he was tired of it, he would leave.
Sometimes he would join the community at Donglin, sometimes he would walk on Mount Nanyue. He understood the essence of the teachings at Caoxi, not needing to stay for even one night;
He visited the immortals at Ruan Cave, intending to reach the Three Purities.
He devoted himself to seeking the truth, never wasting time.
Outside of this, he would gather medicine from the mountains and valleys, and treat the sick among the traveling monks, solely focused on benefiting others, with no other thoughts.

In the fourth year of Qianhua of the Liang dynasty, he came from the Jiang region to the imperial capital. Looking at the various Buddhist temples, he found that they were all complete, but the practice of the warm room for washing away dust and dirt was lacking.

He stayed in Luozhou, digging out rooms, dividing the north and south banks, and building a palace of several mu, marking it with a signboard, and inviting those who wished to cultivate blessings to occupy it.
In less than a year, the construction was completed, and all the bathing facilities and monks' quarters were well-organized.
Thus, the Buddhist community in Luoyang City and the upper echelons of Daoist temples came as if returning home, with no obstruction to those who came.
Every month, after the first five days, he would open a bath once, without interruption.
In a year, there were more than seventy such gatherings;
In each bath, three to two thousand monks from far and near would gather.
Hui personally took on the tasks, never complaining of fatigue.
Moreover, he wore wooden clogs on his feet and stitched hempen clothes. How far apart was he from KÄÅ›yapa?

If he had spare time to serve the monks, when he had leisure from chanting, he would take up the brush and ink - thinking of the blue waves of Jialing and the lotus peaks of Mount Taihua, his spirit would be immersed in them, and he would then create;
the misty scenery of the five streams and the cold forests of the four walls would appear before his eyes, and the summer would be cool!
Moreover, he used his ingenious thoughts to create a water-drawing wheel, which was incomparably swift.
He also constructed sixteen statues in the western wing of the Arhat's bathhouse, as well as a hall for AvalokiteÅ›vara, which was completed after many years.
At that time, Yang Guozhong, the Minister Yang, who feigned madness and was called Yang Fengzi, deeply respected Hui and wrote a stele to praise his virtues.
It is unknown where he ended up.
Biography of Guangsi, the successor of Zhenrong Temple on Mount Wutai in the Jin Dynasty. Shi Guangsi, whose surname was Li, was a person from Wenhui in Taiyuan.
He was orphaned at an early age and was rarely mixed with children.
He had faith in Mount Tai and became a disciple of Hao Wei at Zhenrong Temple.
After receiving the precepts, his character was lofty and majestic. He traveled to Baoshan and went out to seek Chan teachings.
After many years, his learning in both internal and external studies became excellent. His mouth was like a surging sea, and it was truly difficult to contend with him.
Therefore, he made up his mind to cross the heavy lakes and climb the mountains of Fujian. He extensively talked about the world of Manjushri, and those who heard it were awestruck.
King Zhongyi Wang Shi made great offerings of incense and tea and sent envoys to deliver them to the mountain temples!

In the Guiyou year, he arrived in Liangzhe and met King Wu of the Southern Tang Dynasty. He was treated with great courtesy and offered incense, tea, and 10,000 sets of alms bowls to the assembly of Manjushri.
The governors and officials of various prefectures in Wu and Yue all contributed their salaries to the cause.
He then sailed to Cangzhou and transported the materials to the mountain.

At that time, the Great Master for Subduing Dragons was leading the suppression, and the Buddhist community feared him. He dispersed them to various temples and hermitages, equalizing the number of monks.

At that time, the disciples strongly requested him to succeed as the abbot of the temple, and he was appointed as a monk official in charge of the temples on the terraces. He was called the Chief Controller, with the title of Super-Transformation, and resided above the monks, like a giant bird leading the fish and birds.
In fifteen years, he built Buddhist temples, provided meals for monks and nuns, and the number was beyond count.
In the first year of Tianfu, he fell ill and passed away on the fifth day of the ninth month.
His disciples built a stupa to enshrine his spiritual bones and relics, which still exist today.

The Biography of Zunzhao of Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital of the Jin Dynasty, the Biography of Zunzhao of Xiangguo Temple in the Eastern Capital of the Jin Dynasty, Yanqiu The monk Zunzhao, whose surname was Li, was a person from Qizhou.
His ancestors did not serve in government. His mother, Lady Zhang, dreamed that a divine person gave her a precious pearl, and then she became pregnant.
When he was born, he was extraordinary. When he was suckling, he could recognize the joy and anger of people.
As he grew up, whenever he saw a temple or shrine, he would walk slowly, looking back without letting go.
At the age of eleven, he took Venerable Chongyan of Kaiyuan Temple in Bozhou as his teacher.
He recited the Lotus Sutra, finishing two copies. From then on, he was diligent in his studies.
When he was almost twenty, he received the precepts and upheld the precepts firmly like a turning stone.

He sought teachers in Xiluo and asked about the Way in Liangyuan. He first transmitted the Lotus Sutra to Dharma Master Zhiqian. His lectures were refined and penetrated the essence, with full-mouthed criticism.
In the second year of Kaiping, the year of Wuchen, he stayed at Yaoshi Temple in Xiangguo Temple and first lectured on his studies.

In the second year of the Longxing era of the Later Tang dynasty, in the Xinmao year, disciples continued to request his guidance, having already gone through it nineteen times, with more than twenty people ascending to his hall.

By the second year of the Tianfu era, there was the Great Master Jijing of Wutai Mountain, who was proficient in the great sutra of the Huayan. He personally entered the Eastern Capital to present merits for the Jin ancestor's birthday.
Hui looked up to Master Jing, whose eloquence flowed like a river. He respectfully followed and agreed to proclaim the teachings.
Hui's good teachings flowed like a hundred rivers, forming a vast ocean.

Between the Liang and Song dynasties, after Jing stopped chanting, he requested Hui to expound it. The empty hall was filled with people, and monks and laypeople gathered like clouds. They raised funds from the four assemblies to carve the entire Huayan Sutra on stone walls on three sides of the lecture hall.
Alas, oil and silk are easily subject to the disaster of fire;
Carving this on sturdy stone, how can it be harmed by white grubs?
The work was not yet completed, but the donations were already sufficient.

He also summoned monks and laypeople, each reciting one scroll, obtaining 240 people, forming three groups, and held sutra assemblies in the four seasons for nearly twenty years, without any interruption.
He also separately offered water and land Dharma food to ghosts and spirits, all encouraging and inspiring the practice of the bodhi mind.
The imperial court revered him and praised his merits, bestowing upon him the title of True Practice Great Master.

On the 16th day of the first month in the second year of Kaiyun (ä¹™å·³ year), he showed signs of illness and used his staff to instruct his disciples. After finishing, he lay on his right side and recited the Buddha's name. In an instant, he passed away.
He lived to the age of 71 and had been a monk for 51 years.
His disciples followed his last instructions and buried him to the north of the Sui River, on the eastern plain of the temple's estate.
Next, there was Shi Yanqiu of Longhua Temple in Hangzhou, whose surname was Ye and was a person from Jinhua.

During the Zhenming period of the Liang dynasty, he received the precepts and studied the Vinaya at Jingxiao Temple. He had a profound understanding of the secret and profound Vinaya. He was about to transmit and lecture on it, but suddenly realized that the Dhatu-raja SamÄdhi was the solid and firm Dharma.
He then traveled to the mountains of Fujian and obtained the mind seal of Chan Master Changqing.

Returning to Zhejiang, he accepted the invitation of the people of Danqiu and resided at Liutong Temple. His reputation and virtue were fragrant, competing with the fragrance of the pepper and cinnamon trees.
The King of Hannan, Qian, admired his lofty conduct and ordered him to reside at Gongchen Temple.
Later, he returned to Longhua Temple in the state capital, gathered disciples, and lectured on the Dharma.
He personally took the lead in all good deeds and activities, considering benefiting others as urgent, and all offerings were returned to the Sangha.
His room had no locks, and his chest had no locks either;
He did not allow the nuns to pay homage, and he did not seek fame and power.
He always taught the precepts, and people from the four directions gathered. The daily offerings for thousands of monks were never said to be insufficient.
The number of people who ate rice before and after was a huge number of tens of thousands.
In the Jianlong period of the Song dynasty, he passed away at the temple where he resided.

The Biography of Zhiliang of Hutong Temple in Caozhou during the Jin Dynasty, Part 1. The Biography of Zhiliang of Hutong Temple in Caozhou during the Jin Dynasty, Part 2. Shi Zhiliang, whose surname was Huang, was a person from Chengwu in Chan Prefecture.
His mother, Lady Liu, dreamed of several monks sitting in a circle expounding the Dharma to Liu, which was clearly in her ears, and thus became pregnant with Zhiliang.
When he was born and grew up, he had the temperament of a monk, being pure, peaceful, simple, and unadorned.
He resolutely left his parents to become a monk, went to Hutong Temple in Caozhou, and served Master Xingman, providing meticulous care.
After shaving his head and becoming a fully ordained monk, he studied the Four-Part Vinaya and the VimalakÄ«rti Sutra, both reaching the threshold.
He said:
Those who leave worldly life, why be confined to one place or cling to a stump, unable to free themselves from bondage?
In terms of extensive knowledge and insight, they are incapable.

He then took his alms bowl and went south to Hengyang, climbed Mount Heng, stayed at PrajÃ±Ä Temple, practiced the fetal breathing method, and read the Buddhist canon. After finishing, he entered the Min Mountains, with no companions, only his own shadow to keep him company.
He encountered fierce beasts several times, which all wanted to pounce and bite him, but he slowly walked away.
He met the two Chan masters Dongshan and Xuefeng and resolved his doubts about Chan teachings.
If anyone asked questions, he would answer them as if flying, because he had thoroughly understood without reservation.
Later, he returned to his original temple, and the faithful came like returning home.
He provided for the monks with the four necessities, never hearing of any gaps, for over forty years, working himself without weariness.
In the last year of the Jin dynasty, on the twenty-third day of the eleventh month in the dingyou year, he passed away.

At that time, the laypeople grieved like drinking poison, and the monks were hurt like eating raw meat. The beasts lost their ferocity and howled in sorrow, and the birds stopped flying and rolled around.
Some said:
Who will save those drowning in the river of desire and the sea of suffering?
He died at the age of seventy-seven, with fifty-three years as a monk.
His body was cremated, and his relics were enshrined in a stupa in the monastery.
Lang vowed that his robes and belongings would never be washed or handled by women, and he did not make his disciples work.
He used the offerings and treasures without distinction, perhaps because he first followed the Vinaya and later practiced Chan, refining his spiritual abilities.
Li Xuan, the Vice-Prefect of Daming Prefecture, wrote a stele for him.

Shi Hui of Tianshou Chan Temple in the Eastern Capital of the Han Dynasty, Shi Hui, whose secular surname was Ju, was a descendant of Wu, the Marquis of Jingzhou in the Han Dynasty. His ancestors moved to Beiyan and became people of Jimen.
His father's name was Zhigu, and his mother was from the Zhao family.
Hui left home as a child and paid homage to Daoping of Wenquan Temple in Jizhou as his teacher.
When he reached adulthood, he received full ordination at the altar of Baize Temple in Jintai.

During the Kaiping era of the Liang dynasty, he drifted aimlessly on the rivers and lakes, following his fate, and his bowl and robe followed him on his travels through the Jiang and Huai regions. He then reached the south of the Han River and met Yan Jun of Guanyin Temple, who discussed the Way with him, clapping his hands and discussing the mind.
He said:
Have you heard of Chan Master Datong on Mount Touzi?
He replied:
I have heard of him but have not seen him.
Yan said:
You should go there quickly.
When he met Datong, in just a few steps, outside of the lifting up and revealing, he was washed clean and clear, and his mind was at ease.
In the second year of the Qianhua era, he came to the Liang capital and thanked Master Jun, saying:
At first, I was aimlessly on the crossroads, wandering in the vastness of birth and death, confused and ignorant, my madness mingling with the sages.
If I had not followed the guidance of teachers and friends, I would have spent my whole life in vain.
Now, with this filthy and lowly body, I ask to be placed in the same vessel and hidden with the fragrant ones. Is this possible?
Master Jun and the other virtuous ones invited him to stay and join their Dharma assembly.
In the autumn of the fourth year, Zhi Xiu of the Arhat Temple in Baoji Fang earnestly invited Hui to take up residence there, which was only a thatched roof of five bays.

Then he inspired the donors, such as Shangshu Zuo Cheng Wu Ai and Bingbu Shilang Zhang Gun, who were like Yuan Can visiting Bao Liang and Xu Zhanzhi paying respects to Huitong, and together they jointly issued the chapter and bestowed the name Tianshou!
Monks from the four seas gathered like clouds.
For thirty-five years, he provided food for more than two hundred thousand monks, using his wealth and treasures without the slightest confusion or ambiguity, his uprightness can be known.
In the seventh year of Tianfu, the founder of the Jin Dynasty, because Hui's practice was accomplished internally and his reputation was heard externally, he decreed to bestow a purple robe.
In the first year of Kaiyun, he was given the title of Faxiang.
The purple robe was hidden and kept, and the title of master was disregarded and not used.
Moreover, he said:
I originally did not seek fame, but fame came to seek me.
Knowing to be white while guarding the black, harmonizing with the light while sharing the dust, the world's illusions pass by, time does not wait for me.
On the twenty-sixth day of the seventh month in the third year, he entrusted his disciples and peacefully passed away, at the age of sixty-seven, with forty-eight years as a monk.
His body was cremated, and hundreds of relics were collected. A stupa was built in Bianyang Township, east of the suburbs.
Bian Guizhao, the Vice Minister of the Department of Punishments, wrote a stele to praise his virtues.

Biography of Shi Zhijiang of Guangshou Temple in Songzhou, Zhou Dynasty. Biography of Shi Zhijiang of Guangshou Temple in Songzhou, Zhou Dynasty. Shi Zhijiang, with the secular surname Dan, was from Nanguan in the south of the three rivers in Youzhou.
He was the son of a wealthy family and a wanderer. Although he rode on a bamboo horse, he was tired of the gate of the burning house;
When playing with sand piles, he liked to make floating-image stupas.
When he briefly heard the teachings of the Bamboo Grove, he must have had a clear mind and concentrated thoughts, like meeting an old friend in the Xiao and Xiang rivers.
In the fourth year of Qianning of the Tang Dynasty, at the age of fifteen, he went to Ganhua Temple on Panshan and finally became a monk. He completed the duties of a monk.
In the third year of Tianfu, he went to Liyuan Temple on Mount Wutai and received the precepts of a fully ordained monk.

From then on, he carried his luggage to study, seeking a teacher to rely on. He studied the two scriptures of Vimalakirti Sutra and Sutra of the Buddha of Immeasurable Life, and understood them completely, without any dissatisfaction in his mind.

In the first year of Longde of the Liang Dynasty, he lectured on one branch of the Sutra of Names and Numbers at Kaibao Temple in Shangqiu. It is said that his profound understanding of the essence of the sutra spread widely. He then wrote the Commentary on the Sutra of the Buddha of Immeasurable Life in eight fascicles, which was passed on by the wise.
Students followed him like shadows, and many copies were made.
In the first year of Tongguang of the Later Tang Dynasty, he stayed at a temple in the ruins of Qi, building halls and pavilions, which were magnificent.
He also sculpted two statues of Maitreya Buddha and Shakyamuni Buddha, as well as sixteen arhat statues, all painted with colorful colors, resembling the sacred images.

Just as his good deeds were about to be accomplished, he suddenly fell seriously ill. He passed away in the first month of autumn in the fifth year of Xien De of the Zhou dynasty, at the age of seventy-four.
At the time of his death, celestial beings filled the courtyard, as if leading him away. This was a clear response to his vow to be reborn in Tuá¹£ita Heaven.
Li Xuan, a member of the Ministry of Personnel, wrote a stele inscription for him.
The author says:
Previous people established their theories based on the teachings, how can they allow likes and dislikes to follow their emotions, and right and wrong to be based on their views?
Having followed the previous tracks, one should not overturn the later carriages. Why not be careful and follow them?
The author replies:
There are four kinds of people who create writings:ğŸ”½1. Those who strongly disagree with previous explanations, but are vague in their writing;
1. Those who have biased views and misunderstandings, and their understanding goes against the original meaning;
1. Those who enjoy elaboration and dislike conciseness;
1. Those who prefer straightforwardness and find roundabout explanations strange.
If one has any of these, they will create writings.
I have not yet read Jiang's Commentary on Auspicious Responses, but I have heard about it from others and know that it helps the times.

If one does not use it to help the times but changes the teachings of the ancient sages, how is it different from saying, If the old defenses are of no use and are destroyed, there will surely be a failure of water?

Zhou Guangyu, a monk of Zhenrong Temple on Mount Wutai, Zhou Guangyu, a monk of Zhenrong Temple on Mount Wutai, Shi Guangyu, whose secular surname was Han, was a person from Jincheng County in Yingzhou.
When young, he read Confucian books and had the ambition to assist the country and govern the people.
He often had divine people admonishing him in dreams, saying:
You have a great karmic affinity with the Buddha Dharma.
Thus, he joined Zhenrong Temple and served under Fahui, carefully performing the duties of a disciple, carrying his water and fetching his scriptures.

After receiving full ordination, he recited the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra and thoroughly understood it. Every time he reached the passage Rely on the meaning, not the words, he would explain it to his original teacher and seek permission to study. Wei then gave his consent, so he went to the three academies in Taiyuan. He went through the cold and heat, diligently investigating and pondering, changing his lodging several times.
He then lectured on the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra and the Sutra of the Buddha's Life in two sessions. He suddenly said to his colleagues:

I remember that in the past, every time I thought of 'relying on the meaning,' I recently stayed in the academy. Now, lecturing on the two sÅ«tras, exhausting the principles and seeing the nature, knowing the effect and verifying the cause, how can I not rely on the teachings to give rise to practice, avoiding going against the practice of the four reliances?

He then took leave of Jinshui and returned to his former mountain. He wore the Flower Ornament Sutra and circumambulated the Bodhisattva Hall, making six periods of right-turning prostrations to the Buddha.
This was the third year of the reign of Emperor Gaozu of the Jin Dynasty.
His reputation reached the imperial court, and he was bestowed with a purple robe.
The following year, he was given the title of Tongwu.
The monastic officials and the assembly insisted that he preside over the ordination platform, but he declined.
The monastic officials said to him:
Your practice and understanding are both excellent, and you are uniquely virtuous. If this fine jade is not cut, it will surely be seen as weeping blood.
Unable to decline, he ordained three or two people for a few years, firmly seeking to escape.
When the young king succeeded to the throne, the temple lacked a guardian. The entire assembly unanimously proposed:
Who else but Yisu?
He declined, saying:
This mountain is where guests from the four seas come to play. How can I not leave the temple gate for years?
What is needed for the offerings?
Although he declined, he was not allowed to. After that, for eighteen years, he received offerings and donations for more than a million monks.
One evening, clouds and fog both arose, with sleet and snow falling together. Yisu's white silk shawl, three or four feet long, suddenly disappeared.
The next day, at the deep hour, Lian suddenly returned to his old place, perhaps the hidden spirit sent him there?
In the seventh year of Xinding, the year of gengshen, in the tenth month, he showed signs of illness and said to his disciples:

Those who ride dragons are weary of great troubles, and those who sigh for the phoenix are sad at the passing stream. All conditioned things are impermanent, they are of the nature to arise and pass away.
After saying this, he passed away like a cicada shedding its shell.
He was 66 years old in the secular world, and 46 years as a monk.
He was cremated under the eastern peak, and his spiritual bones were buried in a stupa. The relics were to be offered according to conditions.

The Biography of Shi Yanjun of Guanyin Chan Temple in Tokyo, Song Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Yanjun of Guanyin Chan Temple in Tokyo, Song Dynasty, Shi Yanjun, whose surname was Lian, was a person from Xingtai.
When he was born, he showed many extraordinary signs. He vowed to enter the empty gate and leave the secular world.
He followed and held the pearl of precepts, which was perfectly clear throughout his life.
He then carried his alms bowl and staff, traveling everywhere to seek teachings. He climbed Mount Heng and Mount Lu, and ascended Mount Min and Mount Shu.
Once he arrived at Fenglin, he suddenly encountered a deep valley, where he saw a dazzling area with seven treasures spread out in all directions.
At that time, his companions looked at each other and said:
How strange!
Can we pick them up?
Jun said:
In ancient times, people plowing the fields encountered gold as if it were rubble.
If you want to carry it, you will bring disaster upon yourself.
I will use this wild mugwort to cover my head, and use it to provide for the monks from all directions.
After saying this, he left and went to visit the abbot of Mount Touzi in Shuzhou, and asked him:
Where did the guest stay last night?
Jun said:
In the immovable place.
He said:
Since you say it is immovable, how did you get here?
He replied:
How is it moving to get here?
He said:
It turns out you stayed somewhere you shouldn't have.
However, the mountain master silently accepted it.
When Si returned to Zhao, he left Chenliu on his way and reached today's Dongjing.

He met with Liang Shaobao, the Duke of Longxi, who was the younger brother of Zhicheng, the Jiedushi of Heyang and the posthumous Minister of the Court of State Ceremonials. Although he held a noble position, he deeply believed in the empty gate. He discussed the profound with the outstanding, like Liu Yimin's reverence for Jia Yuan.
They discussed together the idea of donating the mansion to build a temple of benevolence.
Si did not refuse, but used it to settle his physical and mental state.

Having examined the Chan room and practiced the ancestral style, those who sought the Way and exhausted the profound filled the halls and houses.ğŸ”½The two emperors of the Zhou Dynasty, Gaozu and Suzong, hid in this place and had a friendship with Si as commoners. Whenever they ascended the abbot's quarters, they would prostrate in worship.

When they ascended the throne, they extended their favor to him. When he reached the court, they would always bow their heads to him. They had high discussions and empty debates, as if they had reached a mountain of treasures.

In the third month of the Bingyin year of the Gande era, he showed signs of illness, lingering for a while. His disciples sought doctors and offered medicine, but he closed his eyes, pursed his lips, and did not eat. He gave instructions to the disciples afterwards, saying they should be cheerful, dignified, and reverent, join their palms, bid farewell to the assembly, and then pass away.
He lived to the age of eighty-five, and sat in meditation for sixty-five summers.
When Jun was granted purple robes by the court, he accepted them but did not wear them;
When he was given the title of Pure Precepts Master, he had it but did not use it.

When he was ordered by Emperor Zhou to use his cane and be lightly clothed, the emperor decreed that the great master should not eat a single meal, and that he should eat ká¹£apaá¹‡Ä«ka food at sunset.
Jun agreed but found it difficult to follow.

His compassion and gentleness pervaded all beings, and his self-restraint expanded to include the three courtyards and one gate - the two halls in the east and west were always filled with several hundred people.
Over fifty years, he provided food for tens of thousands of monks.
Among the Chan monasteries in the capital city, his was the best.
On the eighth day of the fourth month of that year, he was buried in Fengtai Village, east of the suburbs, with a white pagoda standing there.
On that day, each temple in the capital city raised banners and flags, blew conches and beat gongs, following each other for two or three li.
The number of monks and laypeople who sent off the coffin was in the tens of thousands.
Wang Zhizhao, the compiler of imperial edicts, wrote a stele to glorify his virtue.

The Biography of Shi Congyan of Baotansi in the Western Capital of the Song Dynasty, the Biography of Shi Congyan of Baotansi in the Western Capital of the Song Dynasty, Shi Congyan, whose surname was Mi, was a person from Yan.
From the time he could recognize things, he knew to kneel and bow. He was upright and extraordinary, with an open and magnanimous mind.
When he was fifteen years old, his parents allowed him to leave home and become a monk at Huijiaochansi in Bingzhou.
After receiving the precepts, he traveled to the other side of the river, like a whale transforming in the ocean. His peers feared him, all knowing to revere him.
He then cherished his mind in the teachings of the patriarchs, hoping to attack the jade of other mountains.

Thus, he went north to Bingtian and south to Guhai, not fearing evil miasma, only admiring the Chan forest. He joyfully encountered Chan Master Longya Shan and resolved his doubts, becoming a great master.
In the Bingchen year of the later Tang Qingtai era, he returned to visit Songshan.
In Luoyang, he began to settle down, and people's feelings became harmonious. Yan built a Chan hall, invited and gathered the saá¹ƒgha, and made offerings to them.
He passed through the three dynasties of Jin, Han, and Zhou, all of whom bestowed grace and titles upon him, saying:
Fame and disgrace are like a shock, I have long been unstartled!
However, in the realm of conventional truth, I am moved by the secular ruler to adorn decayed wood with brocade and embroidery.
On the third day of the eighth month in the second year of the Kaibao era, he showed signs of illness and passed away.
In the Xinwei year, the fourth year, the reign changed to Quanzhong, and he was buried in a multi-storied pagoda.

The Biography of Changjue of Puzhengyuan in the Eastern Capital of the Song Dynasty, the Biography of Changjue of Puzhengyuan in the Eastern Capital of the Song Dynasty, Shi Changjue, whose surname was Li, was from Chenliu.
ZHAO was born with a unique temperament and extraordinary spirit. When he entered the village school to recite scriptures and classics, all the children admired him.
When he reached the age of 20, he went to Lushan to visit the two forests, climbed the Five Elders, and then paid homage to Chan Master ZONG, becoming his disciple.
In the second year of Qianhua of the Liang Dynasty, he was allowed to shave his head and become a monk.
The following year, at the Ganlu Ordination Platform in Donglin, he received the precepts of liberation.
Afterwards, he cultivated his body and practiced what he preached. Although the three baskets of scriptures were still beyond his understanding, he took mind cultivation as his ultimate goal.
He then entered Wutai Mountain to pay homage to the sacred traces of Miaogiji.

Later, in the third year of Tiancheng of the Later Tang Dynasty, he finally established a small Chan monastery to the right of Lijingshu Gate in the Eastern Capital, and it was named Puzheng by imperial decree.
On the third and eighth days of every month, he held a bath for all the monks in the capital.
If the supply of firewood was insufficient for the hot water and steam, he would always remove the small house and take out the rafters to help with the cooking.

The public and the king respected and revered him, and recommended him for the purple robe, but he firmly refused to accept it. He was only concerned with benefiting others and saving sentient beings as his own responsibility.
On the third day of the twelfth month in the fourth year of the Kaibao era, he fell ill, but was light and at ease without any disturbance.
